questions.text: The right eye of a patient has turned laterally and downwards and he is unable to move his eye medially and upwards. The nerve damage is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Oculomotor nerve Injury to the oculomotor nerve causes paralysis of all intraocular muscles except the Lateral rectus and superior oblique, hence resulting in the abduction of the affected eye Levator palpebrae superioris palsy causes ptosis Pupils are dilated Diplopia

Highyeild:

Paralysis of the third nerve In complete paralysis of the third nerve, there is ptosis, which prevents diplopia . On raising the lid with the finger, the eye is seen to be deflected upwards (divergent squint or exotropia ) and rotated internally (intorted), owing to the tone of the two paralysed muscles. The pupil is semi-dilated and immobile , and accommodation is paralysed . There is a slight degree of proptosis, owing to the loss of tone of the paralysed muscles. There is the limitation of movements upwards and inwards , and, to a lesser degree, downwards. Paralysis of the third nerve is often incomplete, and individual muscles or groups of muscles may be selectively affected. ETIOLOGY: Vascular - Aneurysm (of the posterior communicating, posterior cerebral or superior cerebellar artery) - Atherosclerotic changes +/-co-existing diabetes mellitus - Cavernous sinus thrombosis Neurological - Congenital oculomotor nerve paralysis - Space occupying lesion (intracranially) - Diabetic neuropathy Trauma - Base of skull fractures - Iatrogenic e.g. previous neurosurgery around the oculomotor nerve Inflammation/infection Linked to cavernous sinus thrombosis Autoimmune Possibly myasthenia gravi

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Optic Nerve: causes Visual Field Defects. Option: C. Abducens Nerve: causes lateral rectus palsy. There is an esotropia or convergent squint with a limitation of movement outwards, and the face is turned towards the paralysed side. Option: D. Trochlear Nerve: causes superior oblique palsy. There is hypertropia of the affected eye with limitation of movement downwards and towards the sound side.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of a paralytic squint:

options.label: D
options.text: Secondary deviation is more than primary deviation

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Amblyopia Paralytic squint occurs due to paralysis of EOM occurring either due to nerve palsy. The nerves supplying the EOMs don’t affect the vision so the patient has normal visual acuity . Since the visual acuity is normal there is no amblyopia in these patients whereas it’s common in comitant squint.

Highyeild:

CAUSES: Major Types of Amblyopia Type Description Strabismic Misalignment of eyes (strabismus) results in visual cortex suppression of the visual input of the deviating eye Anisometropic Difference of visual acuity (refractive error) between eyes leads to visual blurring of one eye and visual cortex suppression of the visual input of the blurred eye Combined strabismic and anisometropic Eye misalignment and refractive error leads to visual cortex suppression of the chronically blurred image Ametropic Bilateral, symmetric high refractive error resulting in blurred vision in both eyes and inadequate development of the visual cortex Deprivation Obstruction of the visual axis results in suppression of the visual cortex

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A.Diplopia is the most common symptom in patients with a paralytic squint . Option: B. Compensatory head posture , seen in ocular palsy eg. the face is turned towards the paralysed side in lateral rectus palsy Option: D. Secondary deviation is more than primary deviation. This deviation of the sound eye when the paralysed eye fixates on the target eye is called the secondary deviation and is due to overaction of the contralateral synergist (yoke muscle) of the palsied muscle. This feature is of great importance because when well-marked, it distinguishes paralytic squint from the comitant type in which the secondary deviation is equal to the primary.

Extraedge:

Differential criterion Concomitant strabismus Paralytic strabismus Onset At an early age, initially only periodically At any age, sudden onset. Cause Hereditary, uncorrected refractive error, perinatal injury. Disease of or injury to ocular muscles, supplying nerves, or nuclei. Diplopia None; image suppressed (except in late strabismus with normal sensory development). Diplopia is present. Compensatory head posture None Constant Depth perception Not present. Only present when patient assumes compensatory head posture (see symp- toms). Visual acuity Usually unilaterally reduced visual acuity. No change in visual acuity Angle of deviation Constant in every direction of gaze. Variable, increasing in the direction of pull of the para- lyzed muscle.

questions.text: Neurotrophic keratopathy is due to paralysis of:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Trigeminal nerve palsy Neuropathic keratopathy occurs due to decreased corneal sensation resulting in damage of the trigeminal nerve leading to exfoliation of corneal epithelial cells followed by ulceration Causes : Injury to Gasserian ganglion Leprosy Clinical features- Symptoms Red eye, swollen eyelids and defective vision No pain, no tearing Signs: Ciliary congestion is marked Corneal signs include reduced sensation punctate epithelial erosions Frank epithelial defects Corneal ulcer formation which is horizontally oval, located lower one half of the cornea and grey healed-up epithelial borders Rx - Antibiotics, cycloplegics, lubricating drops Antibiotics, cycloplegics, lubricating drops Lateral tarsorrhaphy to prevent relapse

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. BELL'S PALSY: With facial nerve palsy, ophthalmic signs such as lid malposition, exposure keratopathy , dry eye, and tearing are common. Option: B. FACIAL NERVE PALSY With facial nerve palsy, ophthalmic signs such as lid malposition, exposure keratopathy , dry eye, and tearing are common.

questions.text: Which among the following is not a cause of gradual painless defective vision?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Methyl alcohol amblyopia Toxic optic neuropathy (TON) refers to visual impairment due to optic nerve damage caused by a toxin. Toxic optic neuropathy is characterized by bilateral, usually symmetric vision loss, papillomacular bundle damage, central or cecocentral scotoma, and reduced colour vision . This disease is often underdiagnosed or often diagnosed at a stage when recovery of vision is not possible.

Highyeild:

' OPTIC NEUROPATHIES

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Senile Cataract Stages of senile cataract Option: B. Corneal dystrophy Option: C. Refractive Error

Extraedge:

Causes of Loss of Vision Sudden Painless Loss of Vision Sudden Painful Loss of Vision Gradual Painless Loss of Vision Gradual Painful Loss of Vision - CRAO - Massive vitreous hemorrhage - Retinal detachment (involving macular area) - Ischemic CRVO - Acute congestive glaucoma - Acute iridocyclitis - Chemical and mechanical injuries to eyeball - Retrobulbar neuritis - Progressive Pterygium - Corneal dystrophy - Senile cataract - Optic atrophy - Refractive errors - ARMD - Chronic iridocyclitis - Corneal ulceration

questions.text: A 60-year diabetic male presents to your OPD with a complaint of ptosis of the right eye. On examination, R/E has a vision of 6/60, complete ptosis, down & out right eye. The likely diagnosis is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pupil sparing 3rd nerve palsy The presence of down and out the eye with complete ptosis suggests 3rd nerve palsy . LPS muscle supplied by the 3rd nerve is paralysed leading to ptosis. Down & out eye is due to paralysis of the medial rectus, superior rectus and inferior rectus supplied by 3rd nerve. Coming to pupil involvement in 3rd nerve palsies, it depends upon the pathology causing 3rd nerve palsy. Since the pupil innervating fibres run in the periphery of the nerve are compressed in aneurysms or any space - occupying lesions, therefore , leading to pupils involving 3rd nerve palsy . Microvascular diseases like hypertension and diabetes don't involve papillary fibres hence causing pupil - sparing 3rd nerve palsy.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Since the pupil innervating fibres run in the periphery of the nerve are compressed in aneurysms or any space - occupying lesions, therefore , leading to pupil involving 3rd nerve palsy. Microvascular diseases like hypertension and diabetes don't involve papillary fibres hence causing pupil-sparing 3rd nerve palsy. Option: C. Ophthalmoplegia: Internuclear ophthalmoplegia is an ocular movement disorder caused by a lesion of the medial longitudinal fasciculus. It is characterized by impaired adduction of the ipsilateral eye with nystagmus of the abducting eye. Medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF), is a fibre tract responsible for transmitting information that is vital for the coordination of different eye movements. It is a paired white matter tract passing close to the midline, through the brainstem lying ventral to the cerebral aqueduct in the midbrain and the fourth ventricle in the pons and medulla. Option: D. 4th nerve palsy : Trochlear: eyes turn upward and outwards.

questions.text: When is MRI indicated in patients with 6th nerve palsy?

options.label: B
options.text: Associated pain or other neurological abnormality

questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above MRI brains are indicated in patients of 6th nerve palsy to localise the cause in the following conditions: Option a) Patients younger than 5 0 years Option b) Associated pain or other neurological abnormality Option c) Bilateral sixth nerve palsy Option d) History of cancer Option e) Optic disc edema Option f) If no marked improvement is seen after 3 months or other nerves become involved

questions.text: One week after being involved in a bicycling accident, a 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of intermittent double vision. She reports worsening symptoms when she tries to type on her computer or while buttoning her shirts. Physical examination shows a slight right-sided head tilt. Her left eye is deviated upwards, which becomes even more prominent when she attempts left-eye adduction. This patient's symptoms are most likely due to impaired innervation to which of the following muscles?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Superior Oblique This patient's right-sided head tilt, diplopia, upward deviation of the eye that worsens during adduction, and history of blunt trauma to the head suggest palsy of the left trochlear nerve (CN IV). The superior oblique muscle is innervated by the trochlear nerve (CN IV) and is responsible for the abduction, internal rotation (in cyclotorsion), and depression of the eye during adduction. Impairment of this muscle manifests with vertical and torsional diplopia that worsens when the patient looks down and toward the nose (e.g. while typing on a computer); expected examination findings include mild ipsilateral inward deviation (esotropia), external rotation (excyclotorsion), and upward deviation (hypertropia) of the affected eye. Downward gaze is impaired when the affected eye is adducted. The contralateral tilting of the head in this patient may be conscious or unconscious and serves as a compensatory mechanism.

Highyeild:

TROCHLEAR NERVE IN A GIST ORIGIN MIDBRAIN INNERVATION SUPERIOR OBLIQUE MUSCLE FUNCTION DOWN AND INWARD MOVEMENT OF EYE DYSFUNCTION LOSS OF DOWNWARD, INNER MOVEMENT OF EYE, DYSCONJGATE GAZE

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A . The superior rectus muscle is responsible for elevation, incyclotorsion, and adduction of the eye and is innervated by the oculomotor nerve. Impairment in the function of this muscle secondary to nerve injury would cause vertical diplopia, limitation of upgaze in the ipsilateral eye, and downward eye deviation (hypotropia). Option: B . The medial rectus muscle is responsible for the adduction of the eye and is innervated by the oculomotor nerve. Impairment in the function of this muscle secondary to nerve injury would cause horizontal diplopia, limitation of the ipsilateral eye to the medial gaze, and deviation of the eye outwards (exotropia). Option: C. The inferior oblique muscle is innervated by the oculomotor nerve and is responsible for excyclotorsion, elevation, and abduction of the eye

questions.text: The eye deviates laterally and downwards; the patient is unable to look up or medially; the likely nerve involved is
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Oculomotor Paralysis of the third nerve In complete paralysis of the third nerve, there is ptosis, which prevents diplopia . On raising the lid with the finger, the eye is seen to be deflected upwards (divergent squint or exotropia ) and rotated internally (intorted), owing to the tone of the two paralysed muscles. The pupil is semi-dilated and immobile , and accommodation is paralysed . There is a slight degree of proptosis, owing to the loss of tone of the paralysed muscles. There is a limitation of movements upwards and inwards , and, to a lesser degree, downwards.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Trochlear: eyes turn upward and outwards. Option: B. Trigeminal: loss of sensations over the cornea and skin of the face. Option: D. Abducent: causes adduction of the affected side.

Solution:

III The third, fourth, and sixth cranial nerves innervate the extraocular muscles that position the globes in the orbits. Extraocular muscle paralysis resulting from lesions in one or all of these cranial nerves results in the failure of one or both eyes to rotate in concert with the other eye. The primary symptom is diplopia caused by misalignment of the visual axes, and the pattern of Image separation is the key to diagnosing which particular ocular motor cranial nerve (and extraocular muscle) is involved. With unilateral third cranial nerve palsy (ie, oculomotor nerve palsy) , the involved eye usually is deviated "down and out" (ie, infraducted and abducted ), and there may be partial or complete ptosis . In addition, pupillary dilatation can cause anisocoria (greater in the light), symptomatic glare in bright light, and accommodation deficit that may cause blurred vision for near objects. A painful pupil-involved oculomotor nerve palsy may result from a life-threatening intracranial aneurysm. Therefore, recognition of oculomotor nerve palsy is critical to ensure prompt and appropriate evaluation and treatment. The 3rd cranial nerve palsies can be seen in both nuclear and Fascicular lesions.

Highyeild:

Paralysis of the third nerve In complete paralysis of the third nerve, there is ptosis, which prevents diplopia . On raising the lid with the finger, the eye is seen to be deflected upwards (divergent squint or exotropia ) and rotated internally (intorted), owing to the tone of the two paralysed muscles. The pupil is semi-dilated and immobile , and accommodation is paralysed . There is a slight degree of proptosis, owing to the loss of tone of the paralysed muscles. There is the limitation of movements upwards and inwards , and, to a lesser degree, downwards. Paralysis of the third nerve is often incomplete, and individual muscles or groups of muscles may be selectively affected. ETIOLOGY: Vascular - Aneurysm (of the posterior communicating, posterior cerebral or superior cerebellar artery) - Atherosclerotic changes +/-co-existing diabetes mellitus - Cavernous sinus thrombosis Neurological - Congenital oculomotor nerve paralysis - Space occupying lesion (intracranially) - Diabetic neuropathy Trauma - Base of skull fractures - Iatrogenic e.g. previous neurosurgery around the oculomotor nerve Inflammation/infection Linked to cavernous sinus thrombosis Autoimmune Possibly myasthenia gravi

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B . IV Trochlear: eyes turn upward and outward Option: C . V Trigeminal: loss of sensations over cornea and skin of the face Option: D . VI Abducens: causes adduction of the affected side.

questions.text: This is a defect seen in?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Medial longitudinal fasciculus Medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF), is a fibre tract responsible for transmitting information that is vital for the coordination of different eye movements. It is a paired white matter tract passing close to the midline, through the brainstem lying ventral to the cerebral aqueduct in the midbrain and the fourth ventricle in the pons and medulla

Highyeild:

Internuclear ophthalmoplegia is an ocular movement disorder caused by a lesion of the medial longitudinal fasciculus. It is characterized by impaired adduction of the ipsilateral eye with nystagmus of the abducting eye. Medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF), is a fibre tract responsible for transmitting information that is vital for the coordination of different eye movements. It is a paired white matter tract passing close to the midline, through the brainstem lying ventral to the cerebral aqueduct in the midbrain and the fourth ventricle in the pons and medulla. It is the final common pathway for different types of conjugate eye movements like saccades, smooth pursuit, and vestibulocochlear reflex , and forms a communication between all the ocular motor nuclei Ophthalmoplegia can also occur due to certain toxins . The chief exogenous poisons causing ophthalmoplegia are lead and ptomaines ; the chief toxins, are diphtheria and influenza.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. III. OCULOMOTOR: Ptosis, eye downwards and outwards Option: B. Trochlear: eyes turn upward and outwards Option: D. Abducens: causes adduction of the affected side.

Extraedge:

Lateral Conjugate Gaze Normal pathway CN 6 activates ipsilateral lateral rectus muscle MLF crosses contralateral side and ascends to CN 3 nucleus Contralateral CN 3 activates contralateral medial rectus muscle Both eyes look same direction Interruption of pathway Inability to ADDuct eye on side of the lesion (with contralateral gaze) Nystigmus in ABDucting eye Convergence (crossing eyes) is preserved

questions.text: A male patient presented with signs and symptoms like pulsatile exophthalmos, and chemosis with headache. He also has pain in the eye while moving. The following picture is taken at the presentation of the patient. Which of the following muscles is affected?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lateral rectus In the given question, the muscle affected will be the lateral rectus as the image shows convergent squint which occurs in 6th nerve palsy. The clinical presentation of the patient points towards the diagnosis of cavernous sinus thrombosis which can involve the 6th nerve, as it passes from the inside of the cavernous sinus .

Highyeild:

Cavernous sinus thrombosis is usually caused by a bacterial infection that spreads from another area of the face or skull. Many cases are the result of an infection of staphylococcal (staph) bacteria, which can cause: sinusitis – an infection of the small cavities behind the cheekbones and forehead. Septic CST most commonly results from contiguous spread of infection from a nasal furuncle (50%), sphenoidal or ethmoidal sinuses (30%) and dental infections (10%). Less common primary sites of infection include the tonsils, soft palate, middle ear, or orbit (orbital cellulitis). Staphylococcus aureus is the most common infectious microbe, found in 70% of the cases. Streptococcus is the second leading cause. Gram-negative rods and anaerobes may also lead to cavernous sinus thrombosis. Rarely, Aspergillus fumigatus and mucormycosis cause CST. Aseptic cavernous sinus thrombosis is much less common and is usually associated with other disorders including trauma, circulatory problems, nasopharynx cancers and other tumours of the skull base, dehydration, and anaemia.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Superior oblique will cause hypertropia of the affected eye and head tilt on the normal side. Option: C. Medial rectus involvement will show a divergent squint. Option: D. Inferior oblique is supplied by the 3rd nerve and is not true for the above case.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male patient presented with ptosis in the right eye along with the position of the right eye in primary gaze to be down and out. On further examination, it was confirmed that crossed diplopia was noted and also pupils were normal. What can be the likely etiology of this?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Diabetes mellitus In the given question, all the findings point towards the diagnosis of 3rd nerve palsy, but pupils are normal in this case. This is known as pupillary sparing third nerve palsy . It most commonly occurs in medical disorders like DM or hypertension and not in mechanical causes like- Tumors or space-occupying lesions. B. Aneurysms. Hence the correct answer is option C. In compressive third-nerve palsy , the pupil becomes fixed and dilated due to paralysis of the sphincter pupillae . Ciliary muscle paralysis also leads to loss of accommodation. However, in ischemic lesions, the pupil is spared, and there is no loss of accommodation . The sparing of the pupil is thought to be associated with the micro fasciculation of the fibres that control the pupillomotor function located on the outermost aspect of the oculomotor nerve fibres ; these fibres are spared because they are outermost and therefore less prone to ischemic damage than is the innermost. The most common cause of isolated oculomotor nerve palsy is microvascular infarction which is caused as a result of diseases, such as diabetes mellitus, hypertension, atherosclerosis, and collagen vascular disease and is pupil-sparing

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Meningioma - In compressive third-nerve palsy , the pupil becomes fixed and dilated due to paralysis of sphincter pupillae Option :B . Ophthalmic artery aneurysm- In compressive third-nerve palsy , the pupil becomes fixed and dilated due to paralysis of sphincter pupillae
